blocks.text: School days... (above) Cindy, Nancy and Tamara Thomas School dddays....

Louise has been a cyclist since the first of the year. 

Kathy stands before an ancient pump on the first block of East Vine St., Lancaster. Kathy's a descendant, and she was named after her great-great-grandmother who helped start the business in that building back when it was called "The First National Bank." The bank is now part of the Lancaster City Museum which has many artifacts from this time period including old photographs like one we have here showing what East Vine St. looked like over a century ago!

Cindy's Canasta Club meets at our home - Jerry, Cindy, Lindy, Mickey...Mike, Maryanne, Kathy and Jay.

blocks.text: March 7, 1954 - Kitty, Louise, Grandmother Landreth and Gordon visit French Creek State Park, an area of 5,290 acres lying partly in Berks and partly in Chester Counties. Here in 1720 the second iron ore forge in Pennsylvania was established, the ore being mined in the vicinity. The buildings have been restored as an example of an early self-sustaining industrial community.

blocks.text: April, 1954
Nancy, attired in her new evening dress, attends a dance at the Lancaster Riding Club.
The never ending call for cokes, hot dogs and hamburgers has been temporarily satisfied.

April 4, 1954 - A visit to the Conrad Weiser State Park in Berks County at the edge of Womelsdorf. The memorial marks the home of Conrad Weiser, the famous colonial interpreter and peace-maker during the period of the French and Indian Wars.

HOME OF CONRAD WEISER 1729–1760
CHURCHMAN,COUNSELOR SOLDIER, INDIAN-INTERPRETER,
ACENT,DIPLOMAT AND FIRST JUDGE OF BERKS COUNTY.
HE WAS BORN HERE MANY CONFIDENCE WITH INDIAN CHIEFS.
WERE MENTIONED HIS CHILDREN WERE THE OLDEST BOYS
AUGUSTUS WEISER. HIS MOTHER, WHO IS KNOWN AS THE ELDEST DAUGHTER,
WIFE OF THE LATE JAMES HUNTER AND MELCHIOR WUENGERLEND, THE
PATERFAMILY OF THE LATE CONRAD WEISER, BORN IN AMERICA.
HE DIED PRIOR TO JULY 1760. HIS BODY IS BURIED IN THE FAMILY PLOT
ON A NEARBY ESTATE, INDIAN CHIEFS WERE AS INDIAN INTERPRETER AND
CHIEF OF THE LATE CONRAD WEISER, COLONIAL MAN WHO BROUGHT THIS
COUNTRY UNDER ENGLAND'S RULE. HIS MOTHER WAS BRINGHED FROM
POSTERNITY CANNOT FORGIVE HER SERVICES.
PRESIDENT GEORGE WASHINGTON
CREATED THE MOUNTAIN EAGLE CLIMBING CLUB AND DURING THE 200TH
ANNIVERSARY OF THE SETTLEMENT BY THE TOLTECHENOKIN PEOPLE, JUNE 29-30,

blocks.text: A NEW CHAPTER OF AMERICAN BUSINESS CLUBS IS ESTABLISHED IN LITZTZ, PA. UNDER THE JOINT SPONSORSHIP OF THE LANCASTER AND CONESTOGA CHAPTERS. THERE ARE 40 CHARTER MEMBERS.

(Left) Men who will head the new Lititz Chapter; front row, left to right: Gerard J. Evenwel, first vice-president; Albert S. Ebert, president; Frank P. Wolf, secretary and vice-president; Ray Oatman, secretary. Back row, left to right: Orville F. Over, director; Menno B. Rohrer, director; J. Lloyd Sheaffer, director; and William Scatchard, Jr., treasurer. Absent when picture was taken Dr. Arthur Griswold, director and Herbert K. Wagaman, s.g't. at arms

On behalf of the national association of American Business Clubs, Gordon presents Big Hats to three members of the new Lititz Chapter: Gerard Evenwel, Albert Ebbert and Herbert Wagaman. (newspaper photograph)

blocks.text: Late evening in April.

April 16-17, 1954 (Easter week end), 1954 - Gordon and Kitty make a quick trip to Shelby, Ohio, to visit Uncle Tom Evans, who is ill in the Shelby Memorial Hospital.
Left Lancaster Friday, 5:30 P. M; 30 miles to Pa. Turnpike; Irwin; 10:50 P. M (heavy rain-fall most of the way); Ohio line at midnight, drive 278 miles from Lancaster ; leave Turnpike, drive to 1:30 A. M; 332 miles total.
Saturday: late breakfast at 11:30 A. M; reach Shelby 1:30 P. M; total 406 miles Lancaster to Shelby; visit Uncle Tom; find him much improved ; night at Roy Simpson's home on N. Gamble St.
final visit with Uncle Tom; leave Shelby 10:45 A. M; through Mansfield and Wooster, Ohio, to Turnpike at 3:10 P. M.; arrive home 9:00 P. M.
Friday night spent at these cottages, 54 miles within the state of Ohio.
It is almost dark as we head homeward on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

blocks.text: May 26, 1954 - attending the annual shad roe dinner of ABC at Accomac Inn. Standing: Ed Coe, Ted Grosh, Sam Simons, John Groenendaal, Bud Mearig, Bill Groves, Bob Groff, Nat Hager, George Roundm, Jay Ging-rich, Bob Brown; kneeling: Ray Sy-dantz, Marlin Albright and Gordon. Picture by John Mellinger.
View from Accomac Inn.
Gordon with cigar.

Louise's guest,
Sally Gorman.
Nancy and nine of her school friends celebrate the approaching close of the school term with a "slummer party" at our home. The house barely survives the ordeal.

blocks.text: The evening before our departure, we leave Louise (left) with Grandfather and Grandmother Kreider, and Cindy and Kathy (above) with Grandmother Landreth.

FIRST DAY: Tuesday, June 22 - Lancaster to Pa. Turnpike, to Bedford, off Turnpike to Johnstown, return to Turnpike, to Ohio line, to Akron, Norwalk, Sandusky and Port Clinton for night. 6:45 A. M. to 9:50 P. M. 475 miles.

At Johnstown, Pa. Nancy leaves us to spend ten days with her friend, Betty Demi. Pictured are Nancy, Laura Demi, Kitty and Gordon.
Kitty annand Gorddon.
Back on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, a late lunch at a Howard Johnson restaurant.

blocks.text: The birthplace of Thomas A. Edison in Milan, Ohio.

SECOND DAY: Wednesday, June 23 - Port Clinton, around Toledo, into Michigan, to Adrian, Jackson, Battle Creek, Holland and Muskegon. 8:00 A. M. to 3:30 P. M.
266 miles – total 741 miles.

The first night spent at this new motel right on the shore of Lake Erie at Port Clinton. The heavy clouds are moving away after a storm in the night. Nearby, Perry won the Battle of Lake Erie, September 9, 1813.
The gently rolling, highly arable land of southern Michigan is well suited to farms and pastures. Large white clouds hover overhead far as the eye can see.
At Jackson, Mich. where the Chrysler reaches 100,000 miles, and all the digits return to zero, Gordon keeps his promise to buss the car. At Jackson the Republican Party was formed in 1854.

THIRD DAY: Thursday, June 24; FOURTH DAY: Friday, June 25; FIFTH DAY: Saturday, June 26 – At Muskegon, Michigan attending the National Convention of American Business Clubs. Headquarters, the Occidental Hotel. 53 miles - total 794 miles.
At the Convention we join others from Lancaster: Wayne and Jane Strasbaugh, Dick and Helen Bauman, Bud Mearig.
A bus takes the delegates to a chicken barbecue dinner at the Muskegon Country Club. (Left) Claude, Kitty, Dick, Helen, Wayne and Bud. (Right) After the dinner, waiting for the show to go on.
Swimming in Lake Michigan at the foot of the sand dunes.

blocks.text: Muskegon is the largest port on the eastern shore of Lake Michigan. During the early 19th century fur trading was important, followed by great lumber operations. After furious destruction of the forests, Great lumber but manufacturing plants - automotive and foundry products, Muskegon declined office furniture and billiard tables have created a modern industrial city. Nicolet stopped here in 1634 and Father Marquette in 1675.

Newly elected National Officers of American Business Clubs:
President -------- William J. Kircheim
Augusta Chapter
First Vice-President - William C. Eyke
Muskegon Chapter
Second Vice-President - Joseph F. Prola Springfield Chapter
Gordon was given a standing ovation by the delegates on the convention floor after his report as chairman of the National Expansion Committee.

SIXTH DAY: Sunday, June 27 - From Muskegon north along Lake Michigan to Shelby, Ludington, Traverse City, Petoskey, Mackinaw City, across Straits of Mackinac to St. Ignace, to Sault Ste. Marie. 9:15 A. M. to 9:00 P. M. 318 miles - total 1,112 miles.
BY AND THE FINE
Twenty six miles north of Muskegon we stop at Shelby to visit Ben Nearar, Kitty's brother in law, and his family. Note Kitty base of sign.
"Aunt Kitty" makes a big hit with her niece's and nephews' children. At left, Mary Ellen Norris, Kitty's niece; and her two children.

blocks.text: Lunch at Ludington at Gibbs, which must enjoy a wide reputation for the restau-rant is crowded. All of us eat white-fish for the first time. Our opinion: somewhat flat. After lunch we drive to the beach for a wind-blown look at Lake Michigan.

blocks.text: Northern Michigan is ideal vacation country. The lakes, of which it is said there are more than 6000, stretch in broad panorama from every high point of land. This is the region first visited by the French fur traders and it is a part of the area Louis XIV envisaged as a rich empire in New France. From here the celebrated French explorers carried the standard of the King into the Mississippi Valley.
When the sand dunes permit we get frequent views of Lake Michigan and the numerous bays which indent this large body of fresh water.

pages.full_text:
Northern Michigan is ideal vacation country. The lakes, of which it is said there are more than 6000, stretch in broad panorama from every high point of land. This is the region first visited by the French fur traders and it is a part of the area Louis XIV envisaged as a rich empire in New France. From here the celebrated French explorers carried the standard of the King into the Mississippi Valley.

When the sand dunes permit we get frequent views of Lake Michigan and the numerous bays which indent this large body of fresh water.

blocks.text: KENNEDY RIVER
The Kennebec River emerges from the forests, rushes under our road and soon disappears into the forests on the opposite side.

The city of Sudbury, Ontario, almost as large as Lancaster, has grown up around the huge mines and mills which process copper, nickel and gold in this out of the way section of Canada. The plants are American owned. Wages are high, but it is an expensive place to live for practically all the food must be brought from considerable distances. The bad odors do not invite a long stay.
A bite to eat at Sudbury. The owner professes no great liking for Americans who own the mills.
THIS SALE GALLON'S
Copper fumes have killed all vegetation near Sudbury causing the land to erode, a scene similar to Copper Hill in Tennessee.
Gordon clutches his head when he finds the cost of gas is $47½¢ a gallon - high even with the extra Canadian quart to the gallon.

blocks.text: Our first view of Lake Nipissing (pronounced Nip-a-sing) is from this high bluff.
81 miles from Sudbury to North Bay.

As we approach North Bay, Claude experiences increasingly severe pains in his abdomen, accompanied by fever and profuse sweating. As soon as we enter North Bay we have him admitted to St. Joseph's Hospital for observation. He is in the Hospital until 2:00 P. M. the next afternoon, when with the pain abated but still feverish we start a quick trip for home.

This view of North Bay from a high hill overlooking the town. North Bay with a population of about 20M is larger than we expect. It lies in the center of a vast fishing and recreation area. We are ahead of the "season" by one week.
With Claude in the Hospital, Kitty, Betty and Gordon select a log motel for the nite.
Kiiiiitttttyy pickicks some of the wild flowers which grow in abundance throughout this section.

EIGHTH DAY: Tuesday, June
29 - North Bay due south on
to Toronto, southwest via
Queen Elizabeth Way to
motel near Hamilton. 2:10
miles, plus 30 miles in
North Bay - total 1,680

"au revoir" to North Bay -
with Claude still running a fever, we make him as comfortable as possible in the back seat of the car while Gordon, Kitty and Betty ride in front. There is little time spent in roadside stops. North of Toronto we enter a rich farming area.

blocks.text: We look...but do not buy. Actually we spend less than 48 hours all told in Canada so we would secure no duty exemptions.
Motel near Hamilton, Ontario, where we stop at 8:00 P. M. Claude promptly goes to bed - Gordon, Kitty and Betty have a late supper.

NINTH DAY: Wednesday, June 30 – Hamilton, Ontario via Queen Elizabeth Way to Niagara Falls, enter United States, by-pass Buffalo, to Batavia, N. Y., to Bath and Painted Post, enter Pennsylvania to Williamsport, Lewisburg, Harrisburg and home. 6:30 A. M. to 5:30 P. M. 404 miles – total 2,084 miles.

blocks.text: A snack in Bath, N. Y., where we discover a "Dutchies" are glorified hamburgers at an increased price. We are not impressed.
Back in Pennsylvania again...mountains as we heard for Williamspor. Traffic is light so we are making excellent time.
Claude experiences a complete recovery, and is back on the job the next day.
End – trip to Muskegon and the lakes of Michigan and Canada - total 2,084 miles.
Nancy (center) returns from Johns-town - her first plane trip - with a case of air sickness.

Cindy, Kathy and Louise await the arrival of Uncle Tom from Shelby, Ohio. in early July, his first visit to Lancaster since his illness. (Left) A family reunion with Uncle Tom, Uncle Jim and Grandmother Landreth.

blocks.text:
July 25, 1954 - Our annual one day trip to the Ocean south of Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. There was very little bathing due to an over-abundance of jellyfish. Cindy alone speared eleven and brought them from the water.
Total trip - 274 miles.

blocks.text: July, 1954 proves to be the hottest, driest July in the records of Lancaster County, with only slightly more than one inch of rainfall and 18 days with the temperature above 90 degrees. Here, with a towel around his neck, Gor-don tries to make himself comfortable in the back yard as Nancy takes the picture.
A dinner party in the back yard: Kitty; Frank Buller, Gordon, Bill Huber, Ike Groff', Helen Buller, Marilyn Groff and Ve Huber.

blocks.text: August 12, 1954 - Children of the neighborhood hold the Fourth Annual Talent Show in the Landreth's back yard with approximately 120 people in attendance. A surprisingly large collection of $56.20 is again turned over to Heart Haven. Participants are Nancy, Cindy, Kathy and Louise Landreth, Tamara Thomas, Carole Nolt, and Barbara Moyer.
Nancy is director and announcer.
The Welcome Song features the entire cast.
Skit - Hernando's Hideaway

blocks.text: November 12-13-14, 1955 - With John C. Lingle and Harold M. Reece of Educators Mutual Insurance Company, Gordon attends his third National Office Management Association business conference at the University of Maryland. On Saturday afternoon we see Maryland defeat Clemson in football 16 – 0.

November 20, 1955 - It's getting to be an unfortunate habit, but once again Gettysburg defeats Franklin and Marshall in football 33 - O. A light rainfall during most of the game...smallest crowd in years. Cindy gets in free at half.
